newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Piracy charge puts Singapore in spotlight.
newsitem.headline: Piracy charge puts Singapore in spotlight.

text.p: A police raid and a hail of charges -- vehemently denied -- of software piracy against a top compact disc maker has put Singapore in the spotlight as a bootleggers base.
Five years ago, most illegal software used to be traced to Taiwan, officials of the computer industry watchdog Business Software Alliance (BSA) said on Thursday.
Three years ago, China was most blamed.
"The disturbing trend over the last year is that the counterfeit software is being traced back to Singapore, Malaysia, and also Indonesia," said Ron Eckstrom, a lawyer for Microsoft.

His company was a prime mover in Tuesday's raid on compact disc maker SM Summit Holdings, target of a BSA civil suit alleging software piracy that led to a court authorised search warrant and a 15-hour search of its premises.

Summit adamantly denied any wrongdoing, saying it had strict security measures in place to prevent software piracy in its manufacture of audio compact discs and CD-ROMs for the computer industry, about 20 percent of its business.
But whether guilty or not, the Summit raid has highlighted Singapore's alleged role in the highly lucrative bootlegging business, which costs big companies huge amounts of money.
Just how much was emphasised by Cedric Chan, Singapore executive managing director of Autodesk, one of the other American companies involved in the suit against Summit.

Chan said Autodesk's newly launched AutoCAD Release 14 programme used by architects and engineers, which retails for more than US$3,000, was copied and sold very shortly after its launch for a mere Singapore $14 (US$9.30)
"There is potential in using Singapore as a distribution hub for the region," he said. This was why Singapore's piracy rate had been rising.

The BSA said that while piracy rates were generally dropping in Asia -- admittedly from high bases -- they were rising in Singapore, where illegal software use rose from 53 percent in 1995 to 59 percent in 1996, the highest rise in Asia.
This cost software companies an estimated US$56 million in lost retail sales in Singapore, the BSA said.
Microsoft has been a major activist in attempts to crack down in Singapore, working with police on raids of computer stores.
"Microsoft has declared war on Sim Lim Square and we've been conducting raids every month there like clockwork," Eckstrom said, referring to a building crammed with computer shops.

In efforts to curb piracy, the BSA offers up to S$20,000 for leads that result in convictions and encourages companies to sign up for a corporate audit programme, giving them some immunity from being sued if illegal items are found later.
It was such a tip-off that led to the probe of Summit.
Courts have also adopted stiffer penalties -- jail terms of up to 36 months and S$181,000 (US$120,000) in fines.

Analysts said that whether guilty or not, Summit's reputation had been hurt and its projected profits would have to be revised. The company's 1996 net profit soared 86 percent to S$10.11 million for the financial year ended December 31, 1996.
They said confidence that a customer's copyright would be protected was critical in the software manufacturing business.

"There is a lot of piracy in the CD-audio industry. They might lose a lot of customers as confidence in them was one of the reasons they did so well," said Ian Tham, an analyst with Fraser Securities.
He said Summit's margins were "fantastic" at 20 percent, helped by efforts to protect against piracy such as making and releasing CD's at the same time in different countries.
